newsitem.title: BRAZIL: Brazil ex-soldier runs amok, guns down 17 people.
newsitem.headline: Brazil ex-soldier runs amok, guns down 17 people.

text.p: A former soldier armed with two guns and a grenade ran amok and killed at least 17 people on Thursday in a small town in northeastern Brazil before dying in a shootout with police, a police spokesman said.
Genildo Ferreira started his shooting spree on Wednesday night, killing a taxi driver he suspected of having an affair with his wife, the spokesman said.

He then roamed the streets of Sao Goncalo do Amarante in Rio Grande do Norte state until midday on Thursday armed with a hit list and shot to death at least another 16 people, including his wife and mother-in-law, he said.

"Ferreira heard his wife was having an affair and that people were saying he was homosexual. That's when he went crazy and just started shooting," the spokesman said. "He was armed with two handguns and a grenade."
Ferreira left a letter listing 25 people he wanted to kill and gave some indication as to his motives.

"This was a premeditated crime," the mayor of the town of 65,000 inhabitants, Francisco Potiguar Cavalcanti Junior, told Reuters. "We consider this an isolated case. Our town is a town of peace. The mood here is of sadness and consternation." The town is 1,553 miles (2,500 km) northeast of the capital Brasilia.
The 27-year-old left the military five years ago and was working at a local tile factory.
Two other people were injured in the shooting spree, and police were looking for eight people who were missing and were suspected of having been shot.
A former friend and colleague of Ferreira's, who identified himself only as Genival, told Reuters that ever since his son's death a year ago Ferreira had threatened to kill 25 people.
"He used to be a calm kind of guy, but ever since his son was run over by a car he became a bit strange," said Genival.

Ferreira, who was finally cornered by 200 police officers in a ceramic tile factory where he was hiding out with two hostages, a woman and her young daugher, died in a gun fight with police, the police spokesman said. The two hostages were freed unharmed.
It was not clear whether Ferreira committed suicide or whether police shot him. One of the hostages said Genival had shot himself first before police riddled his body with bullets.
Genival said that three months earlier Ferreira had gone to buy a coffin, telling the undertaker he was going to commit suicide.
